caseStudies.title: Complex Dementia with Behavioral Disturbances
learningObjectives: Differentiate between types of dementia based on clinical presentation
Develop non-pharmacological interventions for behavioral symptoms
Apply appropriate medication management strategies
Understand caregiver support needs

patient.name: Margaret Thompson
patient.presentation: Brought by daughter for increasing confusion, agitation, and sleep disturbances over past 6 months

history.chiefComplaint: Progressive memory loss with recent behavioral changes including nighttime wandering, verbal aggression, and resistance to personal care
history.historyOfPresentIllness: Mrs. Thompson was functioning independently until 18 months ago when family noticed mild forgetfulness. Over the past 6 months, symptoms have rapidly progressed. She now requires assistance with medications, has gotten lost in familiar places, and shows significant personality changes. Recent behaviors include accusing family of stealing, refusing to bathe, and attempting to leave the house at night.
history.socialHistory: Widowed 5 years ago, lives with adult daughter, former elementary school teacher, no tobacco or alcohol use
history.familyHistory: Mother had 'senility' in her 80s, father died of heart attack at 65

physicalExam.general: Alert but appears anxious and suspicious, well-groomed (daughter assists with ADLs)
physicalExam.neurologic: Cranial nerves intact, normal strength and reflexes, mild tremor in hands, gait steady but cautious
physicalExam.cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs
physicalExam.other: No focal neurological deficits, no signs of infection

diagnostics.mmse: 18/30 (significant deficits in orientation, recall, and attention)
diagnostics.imaging: CT head: Moderate cortical atrophy, no acute findings

questions.question: Based on the presentation, which type of dementia is most likely?
questions.explanation: The gradual onset, prominent memory loss, and pattern of cognitive decline are most consistent with Alzheimer's disease. The behavioral symptoms (agitation, paranoia) are common in moderate-stage Alzheimer's.

questions.question: What is the most appropriate first-line treatment for the behavioral symptoms?
options: Increase social isolation to reduce stimulation
questions.explanation: Non-pharmacological interventions should always be tried first for behavioral symptoms. These include environmental modifications, structured routines, and addressing underlying needs.

questions.question: Which medication would be most appropriate to start for cognitive symptoms?
questions.explanation: Donepezil is typically first-line for mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease. It's well-tolerated and has the most evidence for efficacy in this population.

discussionPoints: Non-pharmacological interventions: music therapy, structured activities, consistent routines
Environmental modifications: removing mirrors (reduce paranoia), improved lighting, secure environment
Caregiver support: respite care, support groups, education about disease progression
Safety considerations: wandering prevention, medication management, driving assessment
Advanced directives: discuss while patient has some capacity
caseStudies.outcome: Started on donepezil with gradual titration. Implemented environmental modifications and referred daughter to Alzheimer's Association for support. Behavioral symptoms improved with consistent routines and activities. Patient maintained at home with increased supervision and day program enrollment.
keyTakeaways: Behavioral symptoms in dementia often reflect unmet needs
Non-pharmacological interventions should be first-line for behavioral symptoms
Caregiver support is crucial for successful management
Early safety planning prevents crises

caseStudies.title: Recurrent Falls in Frail Elderly Patient
learningObjectives: Conduct comprehensive fall risk assessment
Identify modifiable fall risk factors
Develop multifactorial intervention plan
Understand medication-related fall risks

patient.name: Robert Chen
patient.presentation: Third fall in 2 months, family concerned about safety

history.chiefComplaint: Patient fell again this morning while going to bathroom, no injury but family very worried
history.historyOfPresentIllness: Mr. Chen has fallen 3 times in past 2 months. First fall was in garden, second while getting up at night, today's fall was en route to bathroom. No loss of consciousness with any falls. Uses walker intermittently but often 'forgets' to use it. Reports some dizziness when standing quickly.
history.socialHistory: Lives with wife in two-story home, retired engineer, walks dog daily (with wife's supervision)
history.functionalStatus: Independent in most ADLs but needs help with medications and transportation

physicalExam.neurologic: Mild cogwheel rigidity, bradykinesia, postural instability on pull test, mild tremor at rest
physicalExam.musculoskeletal: Decreased muscle mass, kyphosis, limited hip flexion
physicalExam.feet: Poor fitting shoes, long toenails, calluses

questions.question: Which is the most significant modifiable risk factor for this patient?
questions.explanation: While Parkinson's disease increases fall risk, the significant orthostatic hypotension (30mmHg drop) is modifiable through medication adjustment and non-pharmacological interventions.

questions.question: Which medication is most likely contributing to falls?
questions.explanation: Amlodipine can cause orthostatic hypotension and dizziness. The significant BP drop suggests medication-induced orthostatic hypotension.

questions.question: What is the most appropriate immediate intervention?
questions.explanation: Evidence shows that multifactorial interventions addressing multiple risk factors simultaneously are most effective for fall prevention in high-risk patients.

actions: Reduce amlodipine dose or switch to different antihypertensive
Improve lighting, especially pathways to bathroom
Physical therapy for balance and strength training

caseStudies.outcome: Reduced amlodipine dose, added PT referral, environmental modifications completed. No falls in following 3 months. Improved TUG test time to 16 seconds. Patient more compliant with walker use.
keyTakeaways: Multifactorial interventions are most effective for fall prevention
Medication review is crucial - polypharmacy increases fall risk
Environmental modifications provide immediate risk reduction
Patient and family education improves compliance with interventions

caseStudies.title: Polypharmacy and Adverse Drug Events
learningObjectives: Apply deprescribing principles in complex polypharmacy
Identify potentially inappropriate medications using Beers Criteria
Recognize drug-drug interactions in elderly patients
Develop systematic approach to medication reconciliation

patient.name: Dorothy Martinez
patient.presentation: Increasing confusion, weakness, and multiple recent falls

history.chiefComplaint: Family reports patient has become increasingly confused and weak over past month, with 2 falls in past week
history.recentChanges: Started tramadol 2 months ago for back pain, increased omeprazole dose 3 weeks ago

physicalExam.neurologic: Mild confusion, slower responses, mild tremor

questions.question: Which medication combination is most likely causing the hyponatremia?
questions.explanation: ACE inhibitors and thiazide diuretics can both cause hyponatremia, especially in elderly patients. The combination increases this risk.

questions.question: According to Beers Criteria, which medications should be avoided or used with caution?
questions.explanation: Diphenhydramine (anticholinergic), lorazepam (benzodiazepine), and tramadol (in elderly) are all on the Beers Criteria as potentially inappropriate.

questions.question: What is the most appropriate first step in management?
options: Continue current regimen but monitor closely
questions.explanation: A systematic approach to identify potentially inappropriate medications and deprescribe when benefits no longer outweigh risks is the best approach.

deprescribingPlan.rationale: Strongly anticholinergic, contributing to confusion and falls. Use sleep hygiene instead.
Benzodiazepine in elderly increases fall and confusion risk. Taper to avoid withdrawal.
Tramadol has anticholinergic and serotonergic effects, increases fall risk. Acetaminophen safer for elderly.
HbA1c 6.8% suggests possible overtreatment. Hypoglycemia risk with weight loss and decreased appetite.
Contributing to hyponatremia and orthostatic hypotension. Reassess need after electrolyte correction.
High dose may not be necessary. Long-term PPI use has risks (B12 deficiency, osteoporosis).

followUp: Assessment of pain management with acetaminophen
caseStudies.outcome: After medication changes, patient's confusion improved significantly. Sodium normalized, no further falls. HbA1c remained stable at 7.1% on reduced diabetes medications. Family reported return to baseline function.
keyTakeaways: Polypharmacy significantly increases risk of adverse drug events in elderly
Beers Criteria helps identify potentially inappropriate medications
Deprescribing requires systematic approach and careful monitoring
Less is often more in geriatric prescribing - focus on quality of life goals

caseStudies.title: End-of-Life Care and Advance Directives
learningObjectives: Navigate complex end-of-life discussions with patients and families
Understand legal and ethical aspects of advance directives
Apply principles of comfort care and symptom management
Coordinate interdisciplinary palliative care team

patient.name: Eleanor Washington
patient.presentation: Advanced dementia with recent decline and recurrent infections

history.chiefComplaint: Family meeting requested to discuss goals of care for patient with end-stage dementia
history.currentCondition: Patient has severe dementia (MMSE 3/30), bedridden for 6 months, dependent for all ADLs, has had 4 hospitalizations in past year for pneumonia and UTIs. Recent weight loss of 25 lbs, difficulty swallowing, minimal verbal communication.
history.advanceDirectives: Has healthcare proxy (daughter) but no specific instructions about feeding tubes or aggressive care
history.socialHistory: Widowed 15 years ago, has 3 adult children who are involved but have different opinions about care

familyDynamics.daughter1: Healthcare proxy, wants 'everything done' including feeding tube
familyDynamics.daughter2: Believes mother wouldn't want prolonged suffering, supports comfort care
familyDynamics.son: Lives far away, defers to sisters but wants to be included in decisions

currentSymptoms: Pain: Appears uncomfortable with positioning, grimaces during care
Respiratory: Occasional congestion, periods of irregular breathing
Feeding: Minimal oral intake, coughs with thin liquids
Behavioral: Restless at times, minimal interaction with environment

questions.question: What is the most appropriate first step in this family meeting?
options: Explore the patient's previously expressed values and wishes
Explain that nothing more can be done
Ask family to reach consensus before proceeding
questions.explanation: Understanding the patient's previously expressed values, beliefs, and preferences for care is essential for making decisions that honor her autonomy, even when she lacks capacity.

questions.question: Regarding feeding tube placement in advanced dementia, what does the evidence show?
options: Significantly improves survival and quality of life
Does not improve survival or prevent infections
Is always indicated for nutritional support
questions.explanation: Research shows that feeding tubes in advanced dementia do not improve survival, prevent aspiration pneumonia, or improve quality of life. They may actually increase discomfort and complications.

questions.question: What is the most appropriate approach to pain management in this patient?
options: Avoid opioids due to risk of respiratory depression
Provide adequate pain control prioritizing comfort over other concerns
Wait for family consensus before treating pain
questions.explanation: In end-of-life care, comfort is the priority. Pain should be adequately treated even if it may hasten death (principle of double effect).

approach: Create comfortable, private environment for discussion
Begin by asking what family understands about patient's condition
Explore patient's previously expressed values and wishes
Provide clear, honest information about prognosis
Discuss goals of care: cure, function, or comfort
Address each family member's concerns and emotions
Provide time for questions and processing
keyPoints: Patient is in end-stage dementia with limited life expectancy
Focus should shift from curative to comfort measures
Artificial nutrition does not improve outcomes in advanced dementia
Comfort feeding allows for dignity and family involvement
Pain and suffering can be effectively managed

interventions: Small amounts of favorite foods as tolerated
Ice chips or popsicles for comfort
Family encouraged to participate in feeding
No force feeding or pressure to eat

caseStudies.outcome: After extensive discussion and education, family agreed on comfort care approach. Patient remained at nursing home with hospice support. Pain and symptoms well-controlled. Patient died peacefully 6 weeks later surrounded by family.
keyTakeaways: Advance care planning discussions should occur before crisis situations
Family meetings require skill, patience, and cultural sensitivity
Evidence-based information helps guide appropriate decisions
Comfort care is active, comprehensive care focused on quality of life
Supporting families through grief is part of end-of-life care

caseStudies.title: Delirium in Post-Operative Elderly Patient
learningObjectives: Recognize different presentations of delirium in elderly patients
Apply systematic approach to delirium evaluation and management
Implement evidence-based prevention and treatment strategies
Understand long-term outcomes and prevention of recurrence

patient.name: Frank Rodriguez
patient.presentation: Post-operative hip fracture repair with acute confusion

history.chiefComplaint: Nursing staff report patient became confused and agitated overnight after hip surgery
history.surgicalHistory: Right hip fracture repair 2 days ago after fall at home. Surgery went well without complications.
history.preOperativeStatus: Independent, living alone, cognitively intact per family, driving, managing finances
history.postOperativeChanges: Day 1 post-op was alert and oriented. Day 2 morning became confused about location, tried to get out of bed multiple times, pulled at IV, not recognizing family members

currentPresentation.cognitive: Disoriented to place and time, thinks he's at home, doesn't remember surgery
currentPresentation.attention: Difficulty maintaining focus during examination, easily distracted
currentPresentation.behavior: Restless, trying to get up frequently, suspicious of staff
currentPresentation.sleep: Minimal sleep last night, kept calling for his wife (deceased 10 years ago)
currentPresentation.fluctuation: Symptoms worse at night, slightly better in morning

assessment.camScore: Positive for delirium (acute onset, inattention, altered consciousness, disorganized thinking)
assessment.deliriumType: Mixed (hyperactive during day, hypoactive at night)

questions.question: Which tool is most appropriate for diagnosing delirium?
questions.explanation: The CAM is the gold standard for delirium diagnosis, specifically designed to identify the key features: acute onset/fluctuation, inattention, altered consciousness, and disorganized thinking.

questions.question: What is the most likely precipitating factor for this patient's delirium?
questions.explanation: While multiple factors may contribute, the temporal relationship to major surgery and anesthesia makes this the most likely precipitant in a previously healthy elderly patient.

questions.question: Which intervention should be implemented first?
options: Remove urinary catheter and optimize environment
questions.explanation: Non-pharmacological interventions should be first-line. Removing unnecessary devices and environmental optimization often improve delirium without medications.

tests: Arterial blood gas if hypoxia suspected
Head CT if focal neurological findings

nonPharmacological: Ensure adequate lighting during day, minimize at night
Hearing aids and glasses if used
pharmacological: If severe agitation poses safety risk: haloperidol 0.5-1mg PO/IV
Consider melatonin 3mg at bedtime for sleep

complications: Increased risk of falls and injury
Increased risk of nursing home placement
caseStudies.outcome: With consistent non-pharmacological interventions and minimal medication use, patient's delirium resolved over 4 days. Returned to baseline cognitive function. Discharged to rehabilitation facility and eventually returned home independently.
keyTakeaways: Delirium is common but often preventable in hospitalized elderly
Non-pharmacological interventions are first-line treatment
Early recognition and treatment improves outcomes
Delirium can have lasting effects on cognitive function
Prevention strategies should be implemented for all high-risk patients
